Entry.Title: Astronomy and astrophysics for the 1980's. Volume 1: Report of the Astronomy Survey Committee

Comments.Comment: National Academy Press, 2101 Constitution Ave., N.W., Washington, D.C. 20418. 20+189 pp. Price \partial 23.10 (1982). ISBN 0-309-03249-0.— Reviews in Planet. Space Sci., Volume 31, Nr. 10, p. 1235; 1983 (@cwyi@D. Williams@cwqi@); Sky Telesc., Volume 66, Nr. 5, p. 418–420; 1983 (@cwyi@P. M. Millman@cwqi@).Contents: Introduction: our cosmic heritage, exploration and understanding, a decade of opportunity. Recommended priorities for astronomy and astrophysics in the 1980s: summary of the recommended program, estimated cost of the recommendations, background and overview, supplementary tabulation of program characteristics. Frontiers of astrophysics: large-scale structure in the universe, evolution of galaxies, violent events, formation of stars and planets, solar and stellar activity, planets, life, and intelligence, astronomy and the forces of nature. Approved, continuing, and previously recommended programs: Space Telescope and the associated Space Telescope Science Institute, second-generation instrumentation for Space Telescope, the Gamma Ray Observatory, level-of-effort observational programs within the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, two major astrophysics facilities for Spacelab, facilities for the detection of solar neutrinos, federal grants in support of basic astronomical research at U.S. universities, programs at the National Astronomy Centers, the 25-meter millimeter-wave radio telescope. Prerequisites for new research initiatives: instrumentation and detectors, theory and data analysis, computational facilities, laboratory astrophysics, technical support at ground-based observatories. New programs: major new programs, moderate new programs, small new programs. Programs for study and development: future X-ray observatories in space, instruments for the detection of gravitational waves, long-duration space flights of infrared telescopes cooled to cryogenic temperatures, very large telescope in space for ultraviolet, optical, and near-infrared observations, program of advanced spatial interferometry in the radio, infrared, and optical spectral regions, advanced gamma-ray experiments, astronomical observatories on the moon. Appendixes: Statement concerning a space platform, organization, education, and personnel, panels and working groups, abbreviations used in text.

Ultraviolet, optical, and infrared astronomy: summary and recommendations, highlights of astronomy in the 1970's, science opportunities for the 1980's, detailed description of the UVOIR program for the 1980's, projections into the future, epilogue. Radio astronomy: introduction: scope of the report, summary of recommendations, description of recommended projects and facilities, scientific priorities, reference to list of radio and radar astronomy observatories. Theoretical and laboratory astrophysics: introduction and summary of recommendations, theoretical astrophysics, laboratory astrophysics. Data processing and computational facilities: introduction, conclusions and recommendations, the trend toward decentralization, theoretical computing, image processing and analysis, data archiving, astronomical data bases, telecommunications, specialized architectures. Organization, education, and personnel: summary of recommendations, maintenance of scientific talent, other issues in the practice of astronomy, astronomy and the astronomers in the 1970's.
